question: Which method demonstrated higher effectiveness in crafting white-box adversarial images against surrogate models in the study conducted in the paper 'On Evaluating Adversarial Robustness of Large Vision-Language Models'?
answer: According to the paper, the MF-it method demonstrated higher effectiveness in crafting white-box adversarial images against surrogate models. This is evidenced by the highest CLIP score achieved with MF-it being 0.679 by BLIP (ViT).
reference: Paper Title: 'On Evaluating Adversarial Robustness of Large Vision-Language Models', Section: 'Empirical studies', \"In Table~\\ref{table:1}, ... we observe that MF-ii induces a similar CLIP score compared to the generated image $h_\\xi(\\boldsymbol{c}_{\\text{tar}})$, while MF-it induces a even higher CLIP score by directly matching cross-modality features.\"

question: What was the result of using the combination of MF-ii and MF-tt methods in enhancing the transfer-based adversarial effects according to the paper 'On Evaluating Adversarial Robustness of Large Vision-Language Models'?
answer: The combination of MF-ii and MF-tt methods was effective in enhancing the transfer-based adversarial effects, achieving significant improvements in generating targeted responses. For instance, it increased the ensemble CLIP score to 0.846 for BLIP and Img2Prompt.
reference: Paper Title: 'On Evaluating Adversarial Robustness of Large Vision-Language Models', Section: 'Empirical studies', Table 2: \"...when we use the transfer-based adversarial image crafted by MF-ii as an initialization and then apply query-based MF-tt to tune the adversarial image, the generated response becomes significantly more similar to the targeted text...\"

question: What is the total number of Black-box Adversarial Visual-Instructions (B-AVIs) generated in the B-AVIBench proposed in the paper?
answer: B-AVIBench generates a comprehensive dataset of 316K Black-box Adversarial Visual-Instructions (B-AVIs).
reference: Title: B-AVIBench: Towards Evaluating the Robustness of Large Vision-Language Models on Black-box Adversarial Visual-Instructions. Section: Abstract. \"We generate 316K B-AVIs encompassing five categories of multimodal capabilities (ten tasks) and content bias.\"

question: Which image corruption method was found to be the most effective in the B-AVIBench's evaluation of LVLMs, based on the average score drop rate (ASDR)?
answer: In the B-AVIBench's evaluation, the image corruption method Elastic was found to be the most effective, with an average score drop rate (ASDR) of 0.18.
reference: Title: B-AVIBench: Towards Evaluating the Robustness of Large Vision-Language Models on Black-box Adversarial Visual-Instructions. Section: Results on Image Corruptions in Image-based B-AVIs. Table: Table 3. \"C-name: Elastic... ASDR: 0.18\"

question: In the paper 'An Image Is Worth 1000 Lies: Adversarial Transferability across Prompts on Vision-Language Models', what is the Attack Success Rate (ASR) for the CroPA method on the VQA_general task when using Flamingo with the target text 'unknown'?
answer: The Attack Success Rate (ASR) for the CroPA method on the VQA_general task when using Flamingo with the target text 'unknown' is 0.92.
reference: An Image Is Worth 1000 Lies: Adversarial Transferability across Prompts on Vision-Language Models, Table 1.

question: What was the ASR of the Multi-P method on the image classification task using Flamingo for the target text 'unknown'?
answer: The ASR of the Multi-P method on the image classification task using Flamingo for the target text 'unknown' was 0.64.
reference: An Image Is Worth 1000 Lies: Adversarial Transferability across Prompts on Vision-Language Models, Table 1.
